Help:Node.title: General Concepts: Proximity
Help:Node.Log:Description:
Title: Proximity
Important Commands: approach, leave, [a variety of prepositions]
Syntax: "$(udat.chatchar)approach Jane", "$(udat.chatchar)sit near Jane", "$(udat.chatchar)hug Jane"
Spatial relationships within a room in $(theatre.gamebrief) are defined via proximities or proxes. Objects can have physical relationships with each other which are defined by prepositions such as "near", "by", "below", "under", "on", and "in".
Within a room in $(theatre.gamebrief) you can move around so that you are near to certain objects. You do this with the approach command: $(udat.chatchar)APPROACH [OBJECT]. You can also leave an object with the leave command: $(udat.chatchar)LEAVE.
You can also be more specific as to what your relationship with an object is by using verbs combined with prepositions: $(udat.chatchar)SIT ON CHAIR, $(udat.chatchar)STAND BY HEARTH, or $(udat.chatchar)CROUCH UNDER TABLE.
And, you can also place objects in specific relationships with each other: "$(udat.chatchar)PUT PLATE ON TABLE, $(udat.chatchar)PLACE BOX NEAR DOOR, or $(udat.chatchar)THROW DAGGER AT NORTH WALL.
Moving into the close proximity of another character (ie "approaching" or "moving near") requires consent. So do certain close proximity actions like $(udat.chatchar)HUG, $(udat.chatchar)KISS, and $(udat.chatchar)SLAP.
See Also: Consent, Manipulation, Movement, Room, Verbs
